website_summaries.verdict: The Elgato Thunderbolt SSD offers speed and convenience for a very high premium. With limited storage and a very high price tag, the drive is only suitable for Thunderbolt-enabled Mac owners with deep pocket and a dire need for a high-speed storage device.
pros: The compact and sturdy Elgato Thunderbolt SSD is the first bus-powered (no power adapter needed) Thunderbolt storage device
cons: The Elgato Thunderbolt SSD doesn't come with a Thunderbolt cable of its own and has just one Thunderbolt port
The drive is very expensive and caps at just 240GB

customer_reviews.title: Great disk until it fails unexpectedly
customer_reviews.text: After 4 years it just stopped working. Followed up with support but the warranty has expired; who gives a 3 year warranty? that's such a small amount of time. Having paid almost 500$ for this at the time seeing it's only 250$ :(
customer_reviews.author: S Likens

customer_reviews.title: Fastest portable drive I've ever used!
customer_reviews.text: I love this drive-I am a digital and 4x5 film photographer and have been doing it for over 10 years. This drive I use as my primary 4x5 file drive for edits. Since 4x5 files are usually 500mb+ in my experience, working on a slow drive is frustrating. With this I can do all kinds of edits and not have any lag whatsoever. And saving is incredibly fast!!! I highly recommend this product to anyone in the creative industry that works with large files!!!
customer_reviews.author: Aaron M. Ramsey

customer_reviews.title: totally changed my workflow
customer_reviews.text: Indispensable for pushing around large files quickly. Tests at 100MBPS write and 160MBPS read. Never dropped a connection. No startup delay. Now all my current project files reside here. When I'm done with a project I archive it to small, bare hard drives using a NextStore DriveDock.
customer_reviews.author: R. Tinfow

customer_reviews.title: Pretty fast--better than Seagate--beware MS Office issue
customer_reviews.text: 1) It did an initial backup of 180 GB in 2 hours on a new Air--not the speed I was expecting, but much better than USB 2.0 and 3.0. 2) Before spending the serious $ for this, I tried the Seagate GoFlex portable drive with T'bolt adapter. Yes, cheaper--but it froze my machine and I had to return it. The Seagate freezing is a known issue with numerous web references and no ready remedy. 3) However, know that after each connection/reconnection of this and other Thunderbolt drives, you will probably need to re-enter your MS Office 2011 activation key. What a pain! More info here--MS is not currently (Aug 12) supporting Thunderbolt: [...]

customer_reviews.title: Unit died within 60 days
customer_reviews.text: It was fast and cool till it stopped working. The unit was suddenly hot to the touch and given its a solid state drive, that did not bode well. It would not mount as a drive after that happened, no matter what I did.

customer_reviews.text: For having only one thunderbolt port on the back - 3 stars. Seems like lots of TB devices ship with only 1 port and only one of these device will be able to connect to your mac at once. Kind of defeats the purpose of TB and the daisy chaining ability no? And they still want $699 for this device ....
customer_reviews.author: Richard_

customer_reviews.title: Overpriced!!!
customer_reviews.text: Honestly, this price tag is so high because of its thunderbolt capability. The truth is that the thunderbolt isn't true thunderbolt capability because of its SATA connected SSD inside. The better thing to do is to buy a Seagate backup plus portable thunderbolt adapter, then buy any 2.5 SATA internal SSD and put them together. You end up saving yourself 400$ and you can get a Samsung 840 SSD which is by far the most reliable SSD on the market with its Tri Cell technology.
customer_reviews.author: JJB
